about

Flowgen generates high-level workflow diagrams from C++ annotated sources.

Modern high-performance computing often involves fairly complex algorithms written in C++. This complexity comes, roughly speaking, from two aspects: the high-level (abstract) design, and the details of the specific code implementation. Code developers would like to disentangle the two. Software documentation for developers does not however offer a human-understandable, high-level overview of what the code actually does. It also fails to keep this overview up to date with the code. Good coding standards and strategies such as code modularity surely help, but cannot substitute for this high-level overview.

As a matter of fact, most codes include comments on the actions being performed in the neighboring lines. Our proposal is to promote them: upgrade them and bring them out. Given that a C++ program has a beginning and an end, both in the main() function, we can collect together these actions plus additional information on the control structures in order to form what is known as a workflow. Moreover, the same idea can apply to code substructures such as other functions than main(), or class methods (member functions). Here we will be dealing with a high-level workflow (technically a UML activity diagram [wikipedia]), in close relation to the high-level design, implying that its actions are written down in a human language, by the code architects/developers, rather than machine-generated C++ statements. The open source Flowgen tool can generate a high-level workflow diagram for each annotated function on the C++ sources.

Flowgen builds on the methodology of Doxygen, the de facto standard tool for generating documentation from annotated C++ sources, so that source code and workflow diagrams are bound together and easy to maintain consistent. Doxygen provides structural information, and Flowgen behavioral one; they are thus complementary. Flowgen is currently being applied to the VINCIA code, a plug-in to the high-energy physics event generator PYTHIA 8, used to simulate proton-proton collisions at CERN's Large Hadron Collider.


In this website we present the annotations grammar (INPUT) and the resulting workflow diagrams (OUTPUT) that are generated with Flowgen. The specifications for this annotations grammar exist in the Extended Backus-Naur Form, .EBNF format. Download the current file from this link [To be revised]. In order to visualize conveniently the .EBNF format, one can use the software EBNF Visualizer.
